Posts.Content:
Boy, I hate it when the site times out and I lost my post!
A SB is an image guided biopsy that uses computer equipment to get a core sample from the 
location specifically identified on the mammogram. It's different in that a wide excision biopsy takes more tissue and has a different level of sedation; this is a very precise method of collecting samples. You'll be on a special table, laying on your stomach; your breast will be suspended through holes in the table. The technicians and Doctor do their medical thing and have you laying very still; the equipment is guided into place and it goes in, takes the sample and gets out. I don't remember it being completely awful, I've gone through better, I've gone through worse.
Don't let the procedure scare you; it's just a very precise method of sample collection. As far as itching..the breast that did have cancer did not itch, my remaining breast..does...go figure!.
Have you talked to your breast surgeon? you haven't mentioned that person; I would suggest that you meet with them too.
Try to let this retreat a little in your head and enjoy the holidays ahead. Let me know what you learn though!...
keeping my fingers crossed for you!
Janice

We went to my cousins afterwards and spent time with family, ate some dinner, which really has been my first meal and came home...much to much activity for one day and the pain on the left is awe inspiring; and not ina good way. Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
dear jmkjjc. No, the 29th will be fine; while cancers cells grow, like anything else in the body, the wait of a few weeks normally does not make a difference in treatment. My mammogram was taken in May, biopsy in June, 2nd biopsy in June, mastectomy in later July. The outcome would have been no different than if it were all done on the same day.
Fast forward, 2 years. they've located something on my mri on June 11th in the other breast; I see my surgeon for a needle biopsy on December 6th.
It's normal to think that people should jump on something so potentially serious; but 2 weeks is not bad at all.
Good luck to you and your mother.
Janice

Monday...I would be calling your State's Health Department, Consumer Affairs, Attorney General...someone!
Take care of you and hubby! and let me know how things are going/

Because the DCIS was so extensive I ended up with the mastectomy; the invasive wasn't as large, and there is a questions as to the real size..anywhere from 7 mm to +1cm; but combined..mastectomy and no radiation; I understand your decision.

Posts.Title: Needle Core Biopsy earlier today

Posts.Content:
Hi js. It's difficult to determine what kind of condition your wife may have; I'm not a Dr. and can only offer my opinion. 
With what you've written, this could be an infection, could be fibrocystic changes, an US will help to identify any changes that may look like it needs a better view; this is a common and reasonable approach to a question on a mammogram.
I know this doesn't provide you with the answers you seek, but in this case, you're going to have to wait until the ultrasound; make sure you get a copy of the films and a copy of the report, you can request these, normally, at time of check in. If you need to see a Dr. after this, search for a breast specialist and not just a general surgeon; having copies of films and reports will help you in any future appointments, if needed, or for historical record too.
Good luck,let us know how it goes.
Janice

Posts.Title: should i get a second opinion or new doctor

Posts.Content:
Before you make a final decision, do try to do this:
Find a certified Breast surgeon. You need to be treated, followed and advised by someone who specializes in breasts....not just a general surgeon.
If you do nothing else...this is most important. You start out with someone who has your best interests at heart and knows what to do.
Look at it this way...you have a fire in the garage...do you call the neighbor to bring over a garden hose?, or do you call the fire department?? same thing...
Janice
Posts.Title: Scheduling a breast biopsy and dont know which to choose. scared and confused.

Posts.Content:
Mrs.C. Hi. Encouraging words, I think you're doing everything you can to stay healthy; I'm envious and have a tremendous amount of respect for you! You know, the biopsy, all anyone can do is give you a 50/50 chance and tell you we'll be here waiting to hear from you tomorrow.
Everyone is different and their experiences reflect that; people come here for reassurance, advice, shoulders to lean on and a myriad of other things. I can certainly understand where you're standing; I was in that same position in 2009; mine turned out positive, at the same time, my neighbor....negative.
So, I don't have words of wisdom just lending you a shoulder and letting you know we'll be waiting to hear from you tomorrow. In the meantime, prayers, good thoughts are with you!
Janice

AgeInfo.Phrase: is give you a 50 50 chance and tell you we'll

Posts.Title: Needle Core Biopsy earlier today

Posts.Content:
Are you seeing a breast specialist?; that would be my first thought. Normally yellow green discharge is not indicative of cancer; reddish is another story.
The nodes are being monitored in a method that is considered safe and reasonable; but you're dealing with this on an emotional level and reasonable doesn't calm your nerves.
You have every right to ask for a biopsy; whether they feel it's necessary or not; insurance may question it, but that is another story entirely.
I tell my kids..what harm is there in asking?, what's the worst that someone can say..no?, so go for it. If you are hit with a brick wall and you feel that strongly about
 it, get a second opinion, but get it from a specialist.
Good luck, and go with your gut.
Janice
Posts.Title: need help in making desicion please

Posts.Content: MrsC....thinking of you :)
Posts.Title: Needle Core Biopsy earlier today

Posts.Content:
Dear Victory. You have every right to be concerned, and my concern is who is following you and coordinating your care! I happen to have a great family practice doc, but not everyone has that. Here is what I would do...and, obviously, insurance plays a role with referrals, etc. I would contact your FP and get in with a breast specialist...not a general surgeon, someone who knows all about
 breasts; in the meantime, be proactive; google certified breast surgeon, (your 
location) and see what pops up..start researching these people.
There can be all kinds of reasons for the symptoms you are having but I'm not a dr., and don't like the idea of supposition. It's Saturday, so today is a good day to start googling, but Monday morning, call your FP..if you don't need a referral, call the breast surgeon office direct...let them know what is going on; they will guide you and they will know about
 your insurance requirements too. Also on Monday, contact the radiology department; get copies of your films, all films (on a dvd), and copies of all reports...you may have to go there to sign a release, although some will allow you to fax these back and forth.
It is important for you to have all of the resources and information available to make sure you get the best care.
Please let me know how things are going for you...
Janice
Posts.Title: Don't know what to think.

Posts.Content:
So much! and your head is spinning too. I'm no dr., but I totally agree with the extra surgery; I think it's a good thing and would cement certain opinions for me. My onco score was quite low and that played a part in my decision to take/not to take AI. My liver values have jumped up and down for years; if, in 3 to 6 months, they're still high, and I mean high, then get yourself to a good GI; having the CT and and lung is good...why isn't he running a PET scan instead? oh well. If you're really concerned about
 the liver function, go to a GI now.
You're pre-menopausal, Tamoxifen is a proven winner on that front; is the duplication of effort (luprin + Tamox) necessary...I have no idea. (I may have read that wrong)..yeah I did... I really didn't want to take arimidex; I tried it for a month or two..stopped it... but everyone is different.
Oh, and just in case..I did not like my first oncologist; not at all, and I asked my family dr. (whom I trust implicitly) for an onco...he sent me to his and I love her. She listened to me, she understood me and she gave me options that made sense. 
You're doing your homework, talk to your dr.'s, get the opinions and knowledge you need to take control of your situation.
with you! ♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Needle Core Biopsy earlier today

Posts.Content:
Dear Worryhubby. I post here and some other forums; the support you get is beyond priceless... This is early, there is hope, there is a tomorrow. My Husband, bless him, gave me my space, and kept me close; he participated in my discussions, my what if's, my fears. Start and keep a dialogue, take your cues from her. My sons are in their late 20's and early 30's and live far from home; they were terrified; a lot of support went to them. Go to her appointments with her, listen and help her remember what is said. Find the best care you can and keep looking forward.
You may think she's not afraid, but I know I was..not of the cancer, but for my husband, my kids and for my self image, of how my husband was going to see me...he told me all the time that he didn't marry my breasts, but it was still a difficult time..reassurance is a good thing.
I think the early stages of this are the worst, primarily because of the unknown and lack of knowledge; but we have gotten better; we just changed oncologists because I didn't care for the one I had and I'm feeling a lot more comfortable; my point here, is that you do still have some control. Stay with us!
Janice
Posts.Title: Sorry I've been "absent" lately...

Posts.Content:
maddening, isn't it! You just want to jump, grab the phone and say HEY!, anxious person waiting here!!! It seemed to me it took two days, but not sure...I believe they did say the day that they would call though.
I toyed with the idea of a double, but no, I went with just the one. 
I ended up with an incredible breast specialist and reconstruction specialist, so all worked out for the best and I haven't lost any sleep over it. I would just remind you that you are the person who is important here and you have the right to ask as much as you need, to get the time you need with any Dr. and be in control of your decisions. If anything, anything doesn't sit right, get with someone else.
Saying that, make sure you get copies of all reports and films too.
Sitting here, next to you..cyber shoulder to cyber shoulder!!!
hugs,
Janice

Here's hoping for you..

Posts.Title: Worried!

Posts.Content:
I'm no expert, but when I was in the breast cancer prevention study (quite a long time ago), I had the same experience, plus some. I think tamoxiifim has certain parameters for usage, but I would think that there should be something else. 
If your Dr. won't talk to you about
 something else, talk to another Dr. I just switched oncologists and I'm glad I did.
Posts.Title: (No Subject)

Posts.Content:
Bev!, hello. reconstruction first...the saga continues! I had the last surgery in May and despite everyone's best efforts, I did develop capsular contracture for the 3rd time. I'm currently going to physical therapy (isn't that a funny one..PT for my fake boobie!!); it keeps the scar tissue formation less dramatic and less painful. I am retiring at the end of December and my recon spl is talking about
 doing a flap; I'm thinking maybe the end of January? Tom and I are going on a cruise the middle of January..so good timing. I either have to have this thing removed and go with nothing or have the flap; I'm leaning towards the flap.
It took 3 tries before they got an onco score last year and it was low, I believe a 9 (maybe 11?), but I think 9; by that time it was already mid to late October. I tried the arimidex for a few months, but felt constantly nauseated and stopped it. I also didn't click with the oncologist...at one point he suggested tamoxifen; even though taking it in the breast cancer prevention trial many years prior, proved that it was to harsh for me, lots of side effects...so, why try it again, and since he knows this, why suggest it?
Anyway, I haven't seen him for some time, I cancelled the last appointment and didn't go back. I saw my surgeon yesterday and she really wants me on something; said my risk was 1 in 10 if I was on something, 1 in 5 if not. I didn't do chemo, nor radiation and because of extenuating circumstances, they did not do sentinel node; although there was 1 or 2 in the breast tissue and they were clear.
In my mind, low onco, ovaries removed in 2004, mid 50's, small inv cancer......I'm not feeling the need, nor the desire to start on one more med. (My husband..different story, he's backing the Dr.)
So, Bev, that's the story!
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content: Let us know what you found out; keeping my fingers crossed!!! XXX
Posts.Title: Complex Cyst - do biopsy or not?

Posts.Content: Evita is FDA approved for breast cancer as well; you should be able to get it; you should be seen more than once a year as well; call the other place and make sure you talk to their billing/insurance office to make sure all is okay for you on that front.
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content:
Hello. I posted here quite a long time ago. I was diagnosed with DCIS, but ended up with a mastectomy after they determined it wasn't the normal DCIS, but aggressive and angry. In the end, the DCIS comprised over 50% of the breast and they also found IDC; the size of the tumor was difficult to tell because the original surgery was done at a hospital out of state. After 3 tries, my onco testing came back as a good score, so that helps a lot. 
Anyway, I have an exceptional PS, but my body isn't acting properly; I've developed capsular contracture twice; I had my 3rd surgery on May 19th; I still have my drains; fighting the adhesion's are a daily issue and I have a blood clot. I'm in PT 3x a week and see my PS weekly to help ward of the CC a third time; if this one fails, I'm out of options. 
They would like me to take arimidex, but my IgG levels are low and they're not sure why, but the arimidex makes it drop even lower.
Anyway, not sure what I want..maybe to feel less alone. I don't know of anyone who has had capsular contracture once, much less twice and counting.
Thinking of all of you fighting this battle every day.
Janice
Posts.Title: Complications from Reconstruction and immune system issues

Posts.Content:
Bev, GMA, thank you for your notes. My PS actually talked about
 the sutures at one time, telling me the same thing and he takes some extra steps?....
I saw my Dr.'s again yesterday. I'm 4 weeks out from the last surgery and on PT days or Dr. visit days, I'm still measuring 100+ cc's in a 24 hour period; this drain isn't coming out anytime soon! I told them how last Friday, they found a blood clot behind my knee; I didn't go to PT that day and the swelling and pain were no fun..no fun! I showed my Husband what they did at PT and he tried..it worked enough to break some of the backlog of fluid. 
I need the PT to help avoid the CC, the PT causes excessive fluid and drainage; the excessive fluid means the drain stays in ..on and on. There's one area that is already developed a bunch of scar tissue; my Dr.'s are hypothesizing that my body is reacting to the extra fluid by developing scar tissue..It's a catch-22 situation..
Thank you for being a shoulder for me to lean on, especially when so many are facing a much more difficult road.
Bigmen, thank you for your prayers :)
Janice
Posts.Title: Complications from Reconstruction and immune system issues

Posts.Content:
Hi Bev. I see a new oncologist on Tuesday; she's closer to home and I'll see if she can understand me and I, her. I'll let you know what comes of it..
Janice
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content:
Hello again. I had my 6th weekly check last Friday; news was not good, I've already developed my 3rd case of capsular contracture; all of the efforts, precautions and extras failed. He removed my drain, which is always a good thing!, but the road ahead for me is to either have the implant removed and have no reconstruction or to have a flap..either tram or lat..he's leaning toward a tram I think. I can't do anything until I retire (hopefully) in February of next year; the surgery...as you are all probably aware requires a lot of time off from work, and I don't have time left...using FMLA or LTD pushes my retirement date back., so we're going to keep working on this thing to keep it from progressing and keep me going until February.
Janice
Posts.Title: Complications from Reconstruction and immune system issues

Posts.Content:
Hi Bev. Met with the new oncologist yesterday. First thing..felt very comfortable with her; she was concerned about
 me, she seemed to care about
 me...she got me. She does not feel the need for me to be on AI. She's concerned about
 the left breast and prevention; but she feels that with 4 checks a year, a mammo and MRI, we should be able to catch anything early on.
She said that with my back in the shape it's in (not good) and oste
openia, she felt that evista may be something we would want to think about
. It not only acts as a breast cancer preventative but would help with the bone issues.
So, it went well, very, very well,, and I'm seriously considering the evista...your thoughts???
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content:
Hi Alcie
I had both the DCIS at 50% involvement and the IDC with some question about
 the size, but that will take 10 pages to write! My onco score was 9 and meds are not my friend either.
I had my surgery in Grand Rapids (1+ hours away) and the oncologist there..well, I just wasn't comfortable with him. This onco is closer to my house and I'm happy.
How far are you from another major (or reputable) practice? It may be worth the drive. I'm thinking about
 the Evista because of the other benefit, that being my bone health.
When was your surgery?, are you not being followed by your surgeons office..at least twice a year? If not, find out why! or start seeing your family practice as well as your ob-gyn. What about
 your mammograms, are you getting MRI's...
I would be concerned too, but I'm with you on the AI's.
Janice
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content:
Hi everyone.
I had a mastectomy on my right breast in July of 2009; breast was 50% involved with DCIS as well as invasive cancer.
Since then, mammograms have been clear, MRI in 2010 was clean; MRI last week...not so clear! I have several cysts, one being complex at 2.1 x 1.2 cm; a needle aspiration/biopsy is scheduled for 12/6.
Normally cysts aren't that big a deal; but a postmenopausal woman with a prior history of HRT and cancer....
Wondering if anyone has faced this one before, or heard about
 it.
Janice
Posts.Title: So here's a situation I haven't seen before...

Posts.Content: Thank you Mrs. C! How are you??
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Dear friends.
I just got home from the hospital today; I'm so very tired and sore. The surgery went very well, and the pain was minimal...until we figured out the this tremendous back pain I was having was referred from the surgical sites.
Just a few words: Emotionally, I'm a mess; I never realized how much I hated that implant until now and how much better I feel now that I look "normal". I got tremendous care and I'm very tired, but very good.
Thanks for your support; I'm glad I went through it..
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Bev! I have to tell you; the last migraine med they put me on not only didn't help, but I gained 20 pounds! My reconstruction docs were ecstatic!!! So yes, not only am I not slim, but I still have the migraines, but apparently put the weight on for a good cause LOL!!
I really just want to get this over with; what is it, including the 2nd biopsy; 4 surgeries with one to go..yeah, I'm ready to be done!!
I'm so glad I have you all!
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Bev & Kat; I've been struggling with a cold, but got the go ahead today from my Dr.'s and the hospital; so surgery is a go for Monday.....hopefully, my fears will remain below the surface until then, but .... yikes!
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Well, the small portion of the rib was #3 and that's near the top, not the bottom ones that RW had done..wow that is drastic!!
My physical therapist is specialty trained in breast massage for reconstruction; I have some scar tissue that has developed but she'll take care of it in no time.
I have had some problems with my abdominal incision, but my third trip this week back to my Dr., and now he's happy. Others here have said they're up and running in two weeks, boy, not me. They told me not to worry; with as much as I've gone through over the past two years, it will take me 3 months to get up to speed; I feel better knowing that.
Drains were no big deal to me; 5 surgeries, drains= pita, but nothing else; exhaustion,loss of energy and loss of interest big trouble for me..and, of course, I developed a urinary tract infection, just like I always do around 1 month after surgery.
Tom and I are heading to the home and garden show tomorrow, walk around the arena for a few hours, (will probably do me in for the day), but being up and moving may be just the ticket too.
I am constantly amazed at the beauty of my reconstruction...keep in mind, I'm 55, so you won't see me as one of Vicki's angels on the catwalk, but oh my, my new breast is perfect, perfect! soft, warm, same size and shape as my other side. The tummy tuck has taken years off my mid section, so, while I have complications, I'm not complaining. I have residual pain from the muscle donor site, but that too will pass. They healed my spirit by recreating my body and I would go through it again.
I find myself being overly emotional; I chalk that up to screwed up sleep patterns, lingering pain and a long recovery, but spring is here and that helps my mood tremendously. It will be 6 weeks on Monday; they told me it will take longer for me, so, like I said, I'm not going to worry about
 it now.
Bev, you are a god-send! MrsC; I'm glad you stay in touch! It seems like I'll be in this recovery mode for a while longer, but at the worst, I'm 1/2 through!
hugs to you!
Janice

AgeInfo.Phrase: reconstruction   keep in mind  I'm 55  so you won't see me

Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Thank you Kat. Because of my work situation, I had a tissue expander after the mastectomy and developed capsular contracture (grade 4). In an emergent situation, it had to be removed and I had a silicone implant inserted..capsular contracture, again, and again. I have failed this type of reconstruction 3 times; all that I have left is the tissue to tissue. This is a muscle sparing free tram; the amount of muscle is less than 3 inches; I retired last week and I will now have the time available to recover. We have researched and studied and discussed my options. Frankly, I will be happy to get rid of this implant and hopefully never have to have one again. 
I am concerned, could say fearful, but I'm going to go through with it; we're working with my gastro docs at Cleveland to calm the reflux and the asthma is getting better because of it... I'm going to keep my fingers crossed!!!
Thanks for sharing your story, I appreciate it :)
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
A remarkable life, a tribute to you, a treasure in Heaven; I offer my heartfelt hugs.
Janice
Posts.Title: My daughter Carolyn

Posts.Content:
Just came home from seeing my surgeon; he/they are beyond happy with the results, my healing, everything! He took out the last drain (HOORAY!!!) and lifted restrictions, except core exercising, he'd like me to wait another month.
whew!, I'm happy, and I have to say, the results are wonderful!! He said the pain will continue to diminish, the lethargy too, but after the marathon I've run, it's a nice way to finish :)
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content: good luck finding a competent, caring dr., I know they're out there!
Posts.Title: Gall of ignorant family physician

Posts.Content:
Well, the last few days have been not so good; been feeling fairly lousy, but I think it has more to do with stopping the norco, and the withdrawal from that. Although sleep was elusive last night, I do actually feel better today; still tired though:) I am amazed at how good I look, honestly; I feel complete!
Things are healing and there's the ouches and tightness and itching and the realization that you just can't do things as quickly, but progress is still being made!
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Hi Bev. mine was a free tram, muscle sparing; so the abdominal tissue was cut free from abdomen and transferred to the breast; microsurgery is involved with that as well to attach the blood supply to it's new source. They have to remove part of the third rib to access the area to attach..who knew???; it's only with the pediculed tram that the tissues stays attached to it's original source and no micro is needed.
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Dawn; caring about
 you and your findings....
Janice
Posts.Title: Lump in breast for three years

Posts.Content:
Hi Mrs. C. My biopsy was done by a surgeon out of my area (that is a whole 'nuther story!) so she called me with the results. 
Breast cancer runs through my family, and although we're not BRCA positive, we get it just the same, so my reaction was not like one might expect; it was..okay lets deal with it, what's next.
I went back to the surgeon and she did a wide excision biopsy; that came back with an aggressive form of DCIS and no clear margins. Long story short, I ended up with a new surgeon an hour from my home and she did a mastectomy; it was the pathology on the tissue from that which created the problems. 
My path report showed the breast was 50% involved with this aggressive form of DCIS and they also found Invasive cancer; my new surgeon was quite angry, because she said it was a complete impossibility for the first pathology to have missed it.
So, here I am now, 1 1/2+ years out; I did not have radiation, I did not have chemo and I did not want to go on an aromatase inhibitor; I did try it, I did stop it. Additional genetic testing on the tissue showed a low score for recurrence ( an "onco type" score).
The problems I encountered have been in reconstruction, not because of my recon spl., but because of other challenges. I never wanted to go with an implant, but I did not have the luxury of taking 3 months off from work, so implant it was. My body doesn't like implants, and I have developed capsular contracture 3 times. I retired at the end of December, and on Monday, I'm going in for the free flap tram reconstruction.
I am a very practical minded person, Mrs. C., and I don't deal well with wringing my hands and wondering what to do. I have to say, I have many health challenges and I've learned to deal with each the same way:
1. learn as much as you can about
 it.
2. learn what your options are and what is best in your mind and heart for you.
3. learn who you can lean on and who will support you.
4. allow yourself time to grieve, time to cry, time to grow and time to overcome.
5. if your Dr.'s don't provide you with what you need, fire them and find one that does.
6. you've already found healingwell, this has been a tremendous source of support and knowledge for me; it helps to have others to talk to that have been through it.
You want to hear something ironic?? After surgery, I contacted one of the local breast cancer support groups..guess what they told me...you didn't have your surgery here, we can't help you!! Holy cow!, who knew cancer was so territorial!! LOL!!
Good luck Mrs. C! Like I said, we're here for you!
Janice

AgeInfo.Phrase: So  here I am now  1 1 2  years out  I

Posts.Title: Needle Core Biopsy earlier today

Posts.Content:
Hi MrsC. How are you doing today?, when do you seen them next? I guess re-reading; you've met with the RO & MO and you have yet to have the lumpectomy?, do I have that right?

Posts.Title: Needle Core Biopsy earlier today

Posts.Content:
Jane, I'm so frustrated and tired...we started with a phased reconstruction at the time of mastectomy using a tissue expander. The plan was to keep this in place until a later date when I could do the full reconstruction. I've developed capsular contracture and I have excessive lymphatic drainage too. The drain from the mastectomy wasn't removed until 6 weeks and only because they had to remove it, I was still draining a lot. Now with the excessive scar tissue build up I have to have the tissue expander removed in about
 a month. I'm truly wondering why I went for reconstruction in the first place!! (and just to help matters, I had shoulder surgery last Thursday...I'm truly ready to jump ship!)
I see my breast surgeon on the 6th and the oncologist the same day...I'm not sure how to address my questions about
 why and could use some advice there!
Janice

Posts.Title: My daughter Carolyn

Posts.Content:
O M G
I am so sorry; I have had similar circumstance, but not at this level, but the horror...I do understand and I did file a complaint. I cannot believe that people behave this way and I just can't hug you enough through this note. 
I went on Ratemds.com and put it there; on Angie's List and posted there and told everyone I could about
 this guy. It's been 15 years, but I still tell people my story. If it stops just 1 person from going to them, then I've won. BTW, I would have your oncologist send him a letter too!
A possibility for you..contact your former Dr. in FL and ask who they may recommend...
Janice
Posts.Title: Gall of ignorant family physician
Oncotype-DX Test & Tailor X Test

Posts.Content:
Check into physical therapy where they use kinesio tape; I'm telling you, I cannot believe how this stuff works of redirecting fluid to establish new drainage channels. I've been going since my last surgery in May, and the difference is wonderful...since it worked so well on me they've started working with other patients who've exhausted other avenues. The person has to be trained in the proper placement, but between the massage and the tape, it has worked wonders....who would have thought that tape could work such wonders (and your insurance should cover it!!)
Janice
Posts.Title: Lymphademia

Posts.Content:
Please check the following link:
http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/paying/no_insurance.jsp
Because of the federal act, there are many options to low/no insurance patients to treat this. The difficulty comes in when you have to dig through the morass of information or misinformation. Most places that provide low/no cost mammograms will also have information for low/no cost treatment.,
This act provides for federal medicaid dollars to be used, so please look into this as soon as possible.
Janice
Posts.Title: Lump in breast for three years

I did for a short time, but stopped it; so I can't give you anything definitive. I know it has come up before, type in arimidex in the search box above and discussion threads should come up.

Posts.Title: is anyone taking Arimidex

Posts.Content:
I was on HRT, at the time it was the lesser of many evils; I was diagnosed with DCIS and invasive BC in 2009..the HRT was stopped at the time of the first biopsy.
It seems a long time to wait for an answer; I had mine either the day after, or 2 days after; given the date of your post you should have your answer; hopefully it was good news.
Posts.Title: Had a biopsy yesterday now the wait.

Posts.Content:
I'm loving you all..thanks for your shoulders and kind words. My PS is now sold on the value of PT, and when my Husband can't go with me, my PT does! So everyone is learning and we're developing a plan for core strengthening and something else that she mentioned...I have my concerns, but today is already better than yesterday :)
Janice
Posts.Title: Complications from Reconstruction and immune system issues

Posts.Content: I think all you can do is wait for the pathology to come back; do you live outside of the US? I'm wondering if you went to Mayo, Cleveland or John Hopkins; some place that specializes in abnormal issues?
Posts.Title: Could it be IBC

Posts.Content:
I think you have a Dr. who would rather be safe than sorry and I would take comfort in that. Lumps, shadows, clusters; everything has a 50/50 chance and with dense fibrocystic breasts you will probably have a lot of these situations.
Take some heart in the Radiologist who feels more comfort with it; but I would recommend that you find a certified breast specialist, not a general surgeon, and work with that person in the future.
Good Luck!
Janice
Posts.Title: Just Waiting...

Posts.Content:
I don't think anyone can give you that answer Sheree; and I'm very sorry to hear about
 your mom's friend. Everyone is an individual and so many things come into play; it could be as easy as allowing yourself to go and, on the other hand, fighting until the end. No one has that crystal ball, and I'm sorry, but no one can give you the answer you're looking for. Instead, I would tell you to stand by your Mom and support her as she supports her friend.
blessings...
Janice
Posts.Title: It started as breast cancer now, bone, shoulder, face and brain cancer.

Posts.Content:
Oh Women of Wisdom, I need your opinions and advice again. I saw my surgeon today; I'm one year and 3 months out; my MRI showed nothing of significance and things are looking up...but...they are insistent that I take an aromatase inhibitor and I don't want to. my onco score was 9, but they say that is if I'm on the med; it would be 18 if not. I don't know if that's true or not... my breast was 50% involved with DCIS and invasive was just under 1 cm.
I have significant sensitivities to meds, all meds and I tried arimidex for two months; was nauseous the entire time..has anyone just not taken them and gotten along fine? 
Let me know what you think, good, bad or in-between!
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors and other news

Posts.Content:
MK, I'm sorry; I'm so very sorry.
♥

Posts.Title: Chuck passed away today.
Oncotype-DX Test & Tailor X Test

Posts.Content:
Hi Jane, I'm stuck in some sort of limbo with mine. My mastectomy was done on July 29th; I had switched surgeons and the new Dr.'s anticipated only extensive DCIS, which I had, but they also found IDC; they didn't do sentinel node.
The oncologist ordered the oncotype and it came back inconclusive...wasn't expecting that one. Found out that the sample that was sent didn't have enough of the cancer cells to test. Now it seems that the pathology lab/dept. whatever, can't find my other tissue samples! They've talked about
 doing an axillary node dissection, but I'm sitting here, almost 9 weeks out and we haven't started any treatment at all. Granted, compared to some of the other wonderful women here, mine is not that bad, but it is very frustrating and frankly, I am not sure what to do at all.
They have a very good website to get information on the on the oncotype and TailoRX www.oncotypedx.com
I hope you have better luck than I!
Janice
Posts.Title: Oncotype-DX Test & Tailor X Test

Posts.Content:
Susie, you are scheduled for regular mammograms, right? Just because I am me, and have had bc, I would recommend a follow-up in 6 months, just to make sure. I'm also glad you're not on HRT; don't play with fire!, I did, it cost me.
Janice
Posts.Title: I'm hoping dismissing lump found over a year ago didn't cost me....

Posts.Content:
Bev, I'm having trouble breathing; still having problems from reflux and acid getting into my lungs, so I'm coughing and coughing. Dr.'s are saying it may be best to postpone the surgery until we can get this under control...again... I had a nissen in 2008 and have had complications; they've gotten worse in the last month. I'm going to wait and see what happens over the next couple weeks; I'm on the schedule, and I don't want to relinquish that until I know I absolutely have to.
I'll let you know! :|
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
MrsC; they do a procedure called DIEP and they take the tissue from you butt! There's much that you can do and it is not too soon to talk to your plastic surgeon, they may even have a breast specialist that they highly recommend.
We're going to have to talk privately about
 pictures and the like; no, I haven't taken any pictures, but my plastics guy takes a bunch of them!! My e-mail is posted, you can reach me that way.
I'm glad you're sounding so good!
:)
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
Hello wonderful women and Merry Christmas to all of you.
I met with my reconstruction specialist yesterday; some may recall that I've "flunked" reconstruction 3 times with capsular contracture and implants. The implants were never my first choice; but because of my work schedule I couldn't take the time necessary to heal for a tissue reconstruction. The original plan (July 09) was to have a tissue expander in place until I retire (which is coming up in a few weeks).
I quickly developed grade 4 capsular contracture and have been battling it since; I'm on my 2 silicone implant since the original tissue expander.
I'm going to have the muscle sparing free tram, the first part of February, in Grand Rapids; do I feel fairly nervous about
 this? you bet! I underwent major surgery at Cleveland in July 08 on my stomach and esophagus and I was becoming close to a basket case with that. Normally, this sort of thing doesn't phase me, but the Cleveland surgery shook me up pretty badly and I can already feel it with this.
Perhaps it's the pain, I don't know; but I sure would like to hear from others who underwent a flap reconstruction!
♥
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content:
I'm two weeks out from the MSFT and have had 2 of the 3 drains removed. I did a lot of core strengthening work prior to the surgery, so while I have pain in left quadrant, I have no problem standing straight.
My back pain is starting to get better, but the lethargy just won't let up! Friday I went with my husband to his PT session; they know me quite well there and I decided to go just to walk around the facility,knowing that there are lots of places I can stop and help if need be. They decided to put me on one of of the recombinant bikes and I very slowly pedaled for about
 7 minutes. Saturday morning I felt like a truck hit me!; but it convinced me that I need to watch this inactivity closely.
Monday I see my family practice doc; he is wonderful and will talk to him about
 continuing some sort of very low profile PT; although my PT people don't require a script
 for me; professional/personal courtesy; it may be best to have something.
I continue to be surprised at the lack of energy; considering the previous surgeries (implant vs recon), this one is really getting the best of me. Still; the difference in my appearance; even though the breast is still swollen, is amazing and based on that alone, I am glad I'm going through this.
I'll continue to post my progress; hopefully it will help someone else thinking of or going into this surgery.
Janice
Posts.Title: Settled on type of reconstruction

Posts.Content: Jane!, so nice to hear from you; how have you been doing?
Posts.Title: Happy New Year!

Posts.Content:
Reposting for LadyGaga:
Wondering if anyone has similar experience.
I had an immediate Tram Flap reconstruction on 14th December 2010, that's 7 weeks ago, since then had one chemo treatment at week 6. I am very thin only 100lbs 5'2' and was not informed that it was not a good surgery to have if you are too thin. I would not have gone through it if I'd known. The surgeons strongly recommended this type of surgery to me and I wish I'd known what I know know.
Since then I have had seromas in the abdomen which is still lingering around and trouble breathing and it's really bothering me as I am now not able to eat much at all. How long will this breathing problem stay? I've spoken to my PS and he told me it's early days and it's going to be more difficult because you are so thin. The chemo seems to have made the situation worst.
I wonder if anyone has had similar problems and if this feeling will go away soon. The muscle is like a rock in the middle separating my body.
How long do I have to wait for it to go down?
Posts.Title: Reconstruction problems coupled with new chemo - for LadyGaga

Posts.Content: I would be truthful with the parents; they may have their own opinions as to whether they want their children to know. If you do tell them, tell the children on a level that they will understand without detail; it's all dependent on how far you want it to go, and what the policy may be at your school. Children have the capacity to understand, worry and care, but you know the age and impacts of the children better than I would.
Posts.Title: What to tell children?

Posts.Content:
Hugs and prayers are going out through this to you and your family. I am very sorry.
Janice
Posts.Title: Hospice will be helping me now.

Posts.Content:
Lori; I am sorry for you and your Mother and I can only reiterate what Bev and harrington 49 have said. I can add this though, another forum on this website provided me with such love, support, information, encouragement, laughter and friendship when it saw me through a different major surgery and post op complications; I have leaned on the good people here and on the other forum through my cancer and reconstruction problems too.. 
I hope you find these tremendous gifts here as well
gentle hugs,
Janice
Posts.Title: Stage IV Breast Cancer

Posts.Content:
Hi. I had the lumpectomy last Friday; the biopsy in May showed a small area of DCIS, 6 mm; the final path from Fridays procedure measured 3.2 cm! We just got home from a sort of discouraging Dr. appt. We met with the Radiation Oncologist; he was wonderful, he said they were all taken by surprise by the size of this thing and were in no way prepared for that finding, nor the finding of a second site.
Because of the size of the mass, I do not qualify for the 5 day mammosite radiation, but instead have to do the 6 week stuff. 
The final path shows that it is fast growing, fairly aggressive and has a high likelihood for recurrence, hence the need for a different type of radiation. My Van Nuys is 7.1; the margins aren't as clear as they would like and tomorrow my surgeon, the RO and the pathologist are meeting, reviewing the slides and determining if they have to do more surgery. The RO has brought up the idea of mastectomy. 
I'll know about
 the surgery tomorrow, this really wasn't the news we had hoped for, but it could be worse; they did not find any place where the cancer was invasive, but because of discovery of the second site and the size of the mass, they may have to go back in. 
How does a mammogram show just a small bit of microcalcifications, but the the lumpectomy come up with 3.2 cm? I think everyone has the same thought too, if the mammo missed something of this size, what else is it missing?
Janice
Posts.Title: Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information

Posts.Content:
Welcome home Kath, I hope you continue to heal and even get some sleep! My condition isn't nearly as serious as yours, DCIS. I had a lumpectomy on Friday, no pain to speak of; I should get the final pathology tonight or tomorrow when we see the radiation oncologist.
Continue to get well!
Janice
Posts.Title: Back home from hospital

Posts.Content:
GMA, Judy, thank you for your notes.
about
 a year and 1/2 ago I was learning I needed a nissen fundoplication; I knew nothing about
 it at all, and the information I was getting made it a fairly frightening journey. I found forums and read, asked and listened and one by one, I dropped out, why? because of the negativity and quarreling that went on between members..except here. Healing Well has been the most exceptional place for knowledge and I don't know who named this place, but my props to them! Because of Kitt, our moderator there and the wonderful people who came before me, I got through my fears, had the surgery, the pitfalls, recovery and I'm on the other side helping where I can now.
I'm grateful for the breast cancer forum as well, I'm finding the same spirit here as on GERD, so it's a comforting place to be. People like you who come in to say hello and offer words of wisdom are priceless and I thank you for that!
---|__ (Janice getting off her soap box and walking !)
There is no talk right now about
 sentinel node, but we have a phone appointment with my surgeon on Wednesday. (I'm in Michigan and she is in Indiana..strange, I know, but I've been with her since she started practicing at Michigan State and then she moved to Goshen and I followed her!). I will ask her about
 it then.
I still have questions about
 the high nuclear grade vs. the architecture of the cells and the spread of the multifocal cells (did I say that right?) and how that affects the treatment decisions. 
If you can think of other questions I should, please let me know what they are! 
Thank you!!
Janice
Posts.Title: Janice - a posting for my GERD Friends

Posts.Content:
Denise & Bill, you are the best! Thank you for continuing to think of me and watching over me! Bill, we are so glad that you are home and getting better..you just continue to do that. Denise, seriously think about
 xolair, I remember them wanting to try that on me, but we tried another route; it is meant for the most complex situations and you fit that, so please think about
 it!
Hugs,
Janice
Posts.Title: Janice - a posting for my GERD Friends

Posts.Content:
To the good women of healing well!
We go back tomorrow to see my PS, the PT has been very helpful; the complete rigid nature has eased; the fluid retention is all but gone, but the basic capsular contracture remains. I don't think my PS is going to change his mind; my family doctor (who knows and cares so much!) does not want me to have the flap...he's concerned about
 my inability to heal well; he's worried that there may be an auto-immune problem as an underlying condition...He tried to talked to me about
 having a prosthetic. I don't want to be a whiner here, but honestly, I have a crap body!, there's more wrong than right. It is hard to maintain a semblance of optimism and I'm struggling to come to terms with the possibility of no reconstruction.
We need to have a heart to heart with my PS tomorrow (who also cares). I go back to Cleveland later this month to deal with other health things, and we're looking at meeting with an auto-immune Dr to delve into this some more.
Reconstruction or not; what are your opinions?
Janice
Posts.Title: Complications from Reconstruction and immune system issues

Posts.Content:
Hi Judy, I've just started this process. Mine started out as DCIS (A little itty-bitty no big deal thing, is the way it was described to me) back in May; I switched surgeons and I just had a mastectomy two weeks ago; they found invasive ductal carcinoma, stage 2, but without lymph node involvement. Because I had major surgery last year and used up a lot of my time I'm not in a position to go through the entire reconstruction process now.
In a phased approach, we've gone with a tissue expander for now; I retire in a year and 1/2 and will finish it then. I've had a good amount of pain, they gave me ultram for it and it work only kind of okay; once I supplanted it with something else, I felt a lot better. I have the pulling and discomfort especially around the fold, I've wondered about
 the length of time that it will take before it stops feeling so odd and the pain or discomfort will stop too.
I've wondered too about
 the TRAM flap thing as well. It is not the method that I want to use, my PS thinks that we'll have great results from that and I've already gotten the sit up talk...a friend though had it 10 years ago and still has problems with her back from it, so I'm no sure I want to go that route.
I'm wearing a Wycoal bra and it seems to be fairly comfortable..not great, but tolerable. Right now, I'm still waiting to get the drain out; it will be 2 weeks tomorrow and I'm still draining a lot.
I'm interested in everyones' discussion here and I hope you continue to heal Judy.
Janice
Posts.Title: BREAST RECON

Posts.Content:
MK, sometimes it feels like there's just no end to the madness!, but you are surrounded by people who love you and care for you. My continued thoughts and prayers are with you.
Janice
Posts.Title: The other shoe has dropped.

Posts.Content:
Frayda, thank you for sharing your story. We did go back on Monday; the DCIS is similar to yours and I am going to have a mastectomy; she told me that they would not be surprised to find an area of microinvasion or outright invasion. 
Because of the high false negative rate we are going to forego the MRI for now, MSU has a new type of mamogram machine that is beyond the normal digital type..I'll be screened every 6 months on the left side to watch.
I'm struggling a bit here, maybe you can give me words of wisdom! This started out as an itty bitty, no big deal DCIS; expected to be 1 cm or less and in a very short time its become just the opposite. The last two days I'm finding myself becoming more emotional about
 this, and that is normally not my style..I cannot reconcile this change very easily. It's still not a fear of cancer, I think its the realization of the magnitude and the fear of what it's going to look like afterwards.
I am going to have reconstruction, but it will be later for so many reasons; I wish I could do it at the same time, but it just doesn't look like that is possible.
Thank you, everyone, again, for helping me down this path.
Janice
Posts.Title: Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information

Posts.Content:
You make me smile Denise! I'm blessed and thankful for you and all the friends we have. Thank you for the beautiful note! (I'm still very concerned about
 your breathing though!!)
Janice
Posts.Title: Janice - a posting for my GERD Friends

Posts.Content:
I had a very peculiar thing happen, I'm scheduled for a mastectomy on the 22nd of July and had some questions about
 the procedure; I spoke to the fill-in nurse (the regular one was on vacation) and when she couldn't answer the questions, I asked my surgeon to call me..she is about
 2 1/2 hours away and has told me before that it's never a problem...I guess it wasn't a problem until the night she called me. 
She called me and boy did she call me, she was rude, hostile, obviously irritated and by the end of the conversation I was very upset. I called my family Dr. and spoke with him and by the next morning I still felt the same way, so 2 weeks before surgery, I fired my surgeon.
So, now I'm in the process of finding someone new; we're meeting with one Dr. on Tuesday and another one on Thursday....we'll see how it goes!
Janice
Posts.Title: Fired my Surgeon!

Posts.Content:
Hi Judy, I'm sorry you've had to go through so much! My PS says weekly fills aren't necessary; he's happy with the size and shape that it is. Today's visit produced a no-go on the removal of the drain; we'll see what the volume is like next week. Thanks for the heads up on the discomfort, because it really is, but, like I always say, it can always be worse! I've switched to Motrin 800's the ultram helped a little as long as I doubled up and 2 hours later followed up with something else. I've heard of Lortab, but know little of it.
I had to look up mastopexy, didn't know what that was! LOL!, but I do now! Right now the plan is to keep the tissue expander in place until I retire and then go for something else. I'm planning on going back to work tomorrow, yes, I know it's Friday, but it's a Friday when most are going to be out of the office, so I can come in and work quietly, then go home and spend the weekend and start up next week, hopefully stronger!
You keep getting better Judy!
Janice
Posts.Title: BREAST RECON

Posts.Content:
Prayers and healing thoughts are going out to all of you.
Janice
Posts.Title: DH finally has a diagnosis.

Posts.Content:
The mammogram showed nothing but a small cluster of microcalcifications and the pathology from the first surgeon/wide excision biopsy didn't indicate anything but the DCIS. What was odd, was when I started asking too many questions of the first surgeon...she got quite angry..which is why we searched for someone new. 
After the mastectomy, my new surgeon was fairly upset..not at me mind you, she said it was an impossibility for the first pathology to have not shown invasive...an impossibility. I don't know why that is, but there you have it just the same. It was because of the mammo and the pathology that they didn't feel that there would be anything other than DCIS. She did come upon 1 node during the mast., and that was negative, but was that a sentinel node? I haven't a clue.
Thinking back on it though, we met with the radiation oncologist at that time, he said this wasn't your typical DCIS, but serious, angry stuff; the first surgeon blew that comment off completely...makes me wonder now. 
We are actually quite comfortable with the new surgeon, even with this situation; it's the oncologist that I'm having an increasingly frustrating time. I have checked out breastcancer.org..
Janice
Posts.Title: Oncotype-DX Test & Tailor X Test

Posts.Content:
Generally speaking, bruising is not an indication of breast cancer, but it is something that should be ruled out. Looking at your age, you may not have had a mammogram before, you may want to ask your Dr. to schedule one, what are some of the side effects of the medications you're taking?
As a rule, any unexplained bruising needs to be checked out by a Dr., if your Dr., is ignoring your concern, find a different Dr. If you have an ob-gyn, you may want to check with that person if the Dr. you're speaking of is your GP.
Janice
Posts.Title: bruises on breasts

Posts.Content:
Thank you all for your posts, my goodness, what wonderful people we have on helaing well! Thank you for your support, information, advice, insight and words to ease a troubled mind. I checked out the NCI website and the information there seems so clear cut, that helped so much.
You have all helped and I so appreciate you taking time to do so; my lumpectomy is scheduled for June 19th and I know all will be well.
:)
Janice
Posts.Title: Need your wisdom on DCIS

Posts.Content:
Hi Judy and thank you too. I posted this on the other forum with the folks that I speak to regularly. I'm feeling a great deal of relief today because of the phone encounter I had yesterday with the head nurse at a reconstructive specialist not far from my home:
~~~
I'm 1 1/2 years from retirement and I am trying rebuild my leave balances (after using them all last summer for the Nissen), so right now I have just enough to cover 5 weeks of being off. That has to see me through the surgery coming up and any follow ups...that leaves nothing for reconstruction. Where I work I do have disability, but it affects my retirement date, my pension and other things, and being so close to that date, I have to keep that in mind.
Anyway, long story short, I was put in contact with an exceptional reconstruction specialist, just 1 1/2 hours from home. I called and his nurse talked with me for 40 minutes and told me so much. The best news ( for me) is that I can wait until after I retire to do the reconstruction! The reconstruction takes 8 to 10 weeks to recover (get this) from the FIRST! phase of the surgery..you have to go back for a second go round 6 months later.
My point, I guess, is that being given the freedom to wait until after I'm retired frees me from the worry that I've been carrying about
 this time issue. I slept last night so soundly, it was wonderful!!!!
~~~
I am, by nature, a control nut. knowledge, order, that's me! The issues I have had with this is not being able to get the knowledge and the the inability to put it into an order in my head to make things work for me. I think, with the conversation I had yesterday, that this is finally coming together and with that comes peace of mind for me....I am so grateful!!!!
Janice
Posts.Title: Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information

Posts.Content:
I haven't a clue!! I meet with the first surgeon on Monday and then we're meeting with a second one on Tuesday. I'm want to check them out, listen and decide on who before the surgery; see what my options are, I have a lot of time to determine which is best for me. I know that one of the recons' nurse that I spoke with mentioned that he would like to speak to my surgeon before the surgery to talk about
 technique..I do like that...so, we'll see.
Just had a call from my surgeons' office; d-day is July 22nd; nothing like a dose of reality to start off a holiday weekend LOL!
Janice
Posts.Title: Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information

Posts.Content:
Hi Judy, thanks for your note, and Bev, thank you too! A follow up call with the RO told me that they are all in agreement that I need more surgery; he said this is not your garden variety, benevolent DCIS; he said this is serious, angry, aggressive stuff and how it's not invasive is a mystery to them; so I may be heeding your words..
We're heading back to see my surgeon tomorrow to go over treatment options; her nurse told me that she will want to discuss both mastectomy as well as a re-excision...how do you make that choice? I'm keeping your counsel in mind and will be back when I have more news
:)
Janice
Posts.Title: Post op visit with Rad Oncologist, with surprising information

Posts.Content:
Hi everyone. I'm happy to say that we are very comfortable with my new surgeon and surgery is scheduled for Wednesday @ 1:00; I'm going with a phased reconstruction...for me that means a tissue expander until I retire in 1 1/2 years then we'll do whatever I decide to do then.....onward and upward!
Thanks again for standing by me https://www.healingwell.com/community/emoticons/smile.gif
Janice
Posts.Title: Fired my Surgeon!

Posts.Content:
Hi Jane, I've been off for awhile, just had shoulder surgery..can't seem to stay away from Dr.'s & hospitals and still hurts to type. The biopsy, compared to shoulder surgery, is a walk in the park... but yes, there is discomfort, for some more than others.
DCIS is cancer that is in the milk ducts within the breast; these milk ducts are quite extensive throughout the breast and the DCIS I had covered about
 40% of the ductal tissue; it looks and acts differently than a lump or a mass. Picture an department store with lots of aisles, these aisles are the milk ducts and the cancer is running down the aisles, but not leaving the aisles to go look at the clothes. It's when it decides to actually break free from the aisle and go look at the clothes that it becomes invasive.
When your tissue goes to pathology is segmented into "blocks", so depending on what is sent you can have many blocks are just a couple. Anyway, to update you on me; this final block had enough cancer cells for the Onco testing; my score?, a nice and cozy 14! So no chemo for me, just Arimidex..the postmenopausal version of Tamoxifen. 
Was my surgery done correctly, I think so, yes. She called me her 1 in a million patients...not necessarily using that exact phrase, but I am very rarely "textbook", so it doesn't surprise me.
I still have to have surgery to have the tissue expander and scar tissue removed; the visit with that Dr. is next Tuesday.
Janice
Posts.Title: Oncotype-DX Test & Tailor X Test

Posts.Content:
Research out of Univ of CA is showing a different side to this equation and with more and more MD's speaking up against the notion of quick to surgery I have to ask these questions and hoping that someone here would have something that would quell the argument I have going in my head.
The personal side to my story involves multiple surgeries and so many procedures over the last few years that I've lost count; throw in chronic daily migraine and I am so sick of Dr.'s that the thought of one more surgery is getting the best of me, especially when this isn't tangible and the diagnosis is contradicted by "experts".
Posts.Title: Need your wisdom on DCIS

Posts.Content:
Bev, thank you, yes, my GERD friends are so wonderful, I'm a lucky woman! 
I've learned more since we posted last; the dcis is multifocal, high nuclear grade and both estro & progest +, so I will be stopping the hrt. The radiation is needed because it is multifocal and while it is not invasive the grade is quite high and the nuclei showed significant amounts of mitosis. The biopsies also show atypical hyperplasia and other abnormalities, so it appears as though I am just an event in the making!
I'm am one of these people who needs massive quantities of data in order to make an informed decision and the information out there is so contradictory; it does not help! I'll be doing the mammosite 5 day radiation, that seems like such an easier way to go.
Frayda, my Dr. agrees with yours; while I tested negative and my cousin did as well, there has to be some sort of genetic turnkey that is responsible for many of us developing this. When I talked to one of my cousins the other night, she told me that she was diagnosed with invasive dcis; according to literature, that too seems contradictory, but there is that point where dcis can turn invasive; hers did and with my being noted as high grade it's likely that mine would have turned eventually too.
Thanks again for your help.
Janice
Posts.Title: Need your wisdom on DCIS

Posts.Content:
gma, my hopes and prayers are with you..
Janice
Posts.Title: This has been the craziest week of my life.

Posts.Content:
Since I lasted posted I was referred to a reconstruction surgeon with an excellent reputation; he was on vacation but met with his nurse. She is absolutely amazing; she provided my Husband and I with more information and confidence than you could imagine. We spoke of the surgeon situation and she referred me to a surgeon nearby and was able to get us in with her last Tuesday.
We spent an hour with the new surgeon and she too is very good; we came away feeling like we were in the best of hands. This new surgeon, the reconstruction specialist all work together with others as needed and are always communicating with each other and you; they've pulled my family Dr. into the mix (even though we live 1 1/2 hours away).
We both feel like we missed a bullet with my other surgeon, even though I had known her for so long. We feel, comfortable, confident and like we're in the best of hands.
Thank you again for your kind words and support, we have a good ending to this story!!!
Janice
Posts.Title: Fired my Surgeon!

Posts.Content:
Hi Friends! I didn't feel it was appropriate to talk about
 this on the GERD forum, it is after all, a completely different issue and I didn't want go into details there.
I've been diagnosed with early stage breast cancer, the earliest possible; it has not invaded other tissues and that is a very good thing; it has been graded as high nuclear grade, which from what I understand, is a faster growing, more apt to be invasive type of cancer. 
It has been found in all 4 of the samples and it's called multifocal; right now I'm looking at a lumpectomy, which is scheduled for Friday, June 19th and then following up with radiation. The radiation is a newer kind, which is only 5 days instead of 6 weeks. It's more intense and done from inside the breast as opposed to the lower dosage, external radiation, but 5 days instead of 6 weeks..yay!
I have a phone appointment with my Dr. on Wednesday, we still have some questions; I've learned a lot since we first found out, but still some questions remain and those questions affect some treatment options, so we'll see.
Compared to what some of the other good women on this forum are going through, this is not that big a deal, but I appreciate your support, friendship and hugs!
Janice
Posts.Title: Janice - a posting for my GERD Friends

Posts.Content:
The cure rate Teala is in the 90th percentile!, especially when you couple it with radiation. We still have to have some info on the aggressiveness, but that is just additional information at this point. I found out about
 3 weeks ago now, and I really don't want you to feel badly about
 this at all! This is why you get a yearly mammogram..a digital one at that!!!
Until pathology tells us differently, we're moving forward with a lumpectomy; my Dr. will take a certain amount of tissue which will be checked right away for clear margins. You want a certain edge of normal tissue surrounding the cancerous stuff, because they found it in a couple of places, even though they may be small, the final pathology may dictate more surgery. 
I didn't feel it was appropriate to talk at length about
 it on our GERD forum and I knew you were wondering where this was coming from, so I thought posting here was a good idea.
Do not feel badly! there are others who aren't as lucky as I am; I am grateful for our friendship and the friendship we all share on the forum!!
Bill, once you're out of the hospital you can spend energy on me!!, until then buddy...GET WELL!!!!! (You should ask if you can take Beaker home with you though!!! ha ha !!)
Janice
Posts.Title: Janice - a posting for my GERD Friends

Posts.Content:
I used to post on the GERD forum (Kitt is an AMAZING! woman!), bu this is my first here. 
 I need your wisdom and advice. I have an extensive family history of breast cancer and have had biopsies and close calls, etc. Now I've had another mammogram with a call back and they found a cluster of microcalcifications; another trip to my specialist where she did a stereotactic biopsy. The result are back with DCIS, Grade 0, 6mm; recommendation: lumpectomy followed by 5 day mammosite radiation.
I'm a realist, I'm not afraid of a diagnosis; you can't be, not in my family, but what I can't wrap my head around is the need for any treatment for this. I've read that this is not a cancer, but a pre-cancer; another says, it is a cancer, but not invasive, but it may become invasive if left untreated.
A chance of this becoming a slow growing "real" cancer is not, to me, a reason to jump into a surgical intervention right now. Because of a long standing issue, I have been on estratest (ovaries and fallopian tubes removed in 04); I am more inclined to stop the HRT and wait 6 months to see if there is a change in the mammogram, rather than go in for another surgery. I've had genetic testing, I am not BRCA positive.
Does anyone, anyone, have words of wisdom that will help me to determine if this is a reasonable course of action? Am I just in denial, or is this the result of being diagnosed with a "less than" type of situation than my mother, sister, aunts and cousins?
Posts.Title: Need your wisdom on DCIS

Posts.Content:
Thanks for your answers, it does help to put things in perspective.
Janice
Posts.Title: Need your wisdom on DCIS

Age.Phrase: reconstruction   keep in mind  I'm 55  so you won't see me

PatientDecided.Sample: Because of the size of the mass, I do not qualify for the 5 day mammosite radiation, but instead have to do the 6 week stuff. The final path shows that it is fast growing, fairly aggressive and has a high likelihood for recurrence, hence the need for a different type of radiation....I'm am one of these people who needs massive quantities of data in order to make an informed decision and the information out there is so contradictory; it does not help! I'll be doing the mammosite 5 day radiation, that seems like such an easier way to go....My path report showed the breast was 50% involved with this aggressive form of DCIS and they also found Invasive cancer; my new surgeon was quite angry, because she said it was a complete impossibility for the first pathology to have missed it. So, here I am now, 1 1/2+ years out; I did not have radiation, I did not have chemo and I did not want to go on an aromatase inhibitor; I did try it, I did stop it....I didn't do chemo, nor radiation and because of extenuating circumstances, they did not do sentinel node; although there was 1 or 2 in the breast tissue and they were clear. In my mind, low onco, ovaries removed in 2004, mid 50's, small inv cancer......I'm not feeling the need, nor the desire to start on one more med....The radiation is needed because it is multifocal and while it is not invasive the grade is quite high and the nuclei showed significant amounts of mitosis. The biopsies also show atypical hyperplasia and other abnormalities, so it appears as though I am just an event in the making!...I've learned more since we posted last; the dcis is multifocal, high nuclear grade and both estro & progest +, so I will be stopping the hrt. The radiation is needed because it is multifocal and while it is not invasive the grade is quite high and the nuclei showed significant amounts of mitosis....We met with the Radiation Oncologist; he was wonderful, he said they were all taken by surprise by the size of this thing and were in no way prepared for that finding, nor the finding of a second site. Because of the size of the mass, I do not qualify for the 5 day mammosite radiation, but instead have to do the 6 week stuff....I saw my surgeon yesterday and she really wants me on something; said my risk was 1 in 10 if I was on something, 1 in 5 if not. I didn't do chemo, nor radiation and because of extenuating circumstances, they did not do sentinel node; although there was 1 or 2 in the breast tissue and they were clear....
